head.title: High-Performance Flexible InAs Thin-Film Photodetector Arrays with Heteroepitaxial Growth Using an Abruptly Graded InxAl1–xAs Buffer | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: High-Performance Flexible InAs Thin-Film Photodetector Arrays with Heteroepitaxial Growth Using an Abruptly Graded InxAl1–xAs Buffer

Current infrared thermal image sensors are mainly based on planar firm substrates, but the rigid form factor appears to restrain the versatility of their applications. For wearable health monitoring and implanted biomedical sensing, transfer of active device layers onto a flexible substrate is required while controlling the high-quality crystalline interface. Here, we demonstrate high-detectivity flexible InAs thin-film mid-infrared photodetector arrays through high-yield wafer bonding and a heteroepitaxial lift-off process. An abruptly graded InxAl1–xAs (0.5 < x < 1) buffer was found to drastically improve the lift-off interface morphology and reduce the threading dislocation density twice, compared to the conventional linear grading method. Also, our flexible InAs photodetectors showed excellent optical performance with high mechanical robustness, a peak room-temperature specific detectivity of 1.21 × 109 cm-Hz1/2/W at 3.4 μm, and excellent device reliability. This flexible InAs photodetector enabled by the heteroepitaxial lift-off method shows promise for next-generation thermal image sensors.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

a.title: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

img.alt: Go to ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

div.p:
Current infrared thermal image sensors are mainly based on planar firm substrates, but the rigid form factor appears to restrain the versatility of their applications. For wearable health monitoring and implanted biomedical sensing, transfer of active device layers onto a flexible substrate is required while controlling the high-quality crystalline interface. Here, we demonstrate high-detectivity flexible InAs thin-film mid-infrared photodetector arrays through high-yield wafer bonding and a heteroepitaxial lift-off process. An abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As (0.5 <
x
< 1) buffer was found to drastically improve the lift-off interface morphology and reduce the threading dislocation density twice, compared to the conventional linear grading method. Also, our flexible InAs photodetectors showed excellent optical performance with high mechanical robustness, a peak room-temperature specific detectivity of 1.21 × 10
9
cm-Hz
1/2
/W at 3.4 μm, and excellent device reliability. This flexible InAs photodetector enabled by the heteroepitaxial lift-off method shows promise for next-generation thermal image sensors.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Beyond military and industrial applications, the importance of infrared photodetectors (PDs) is rapidly increasing with the emergence of advanced imaging systems in biomedical and wearable applications.
(1−4)
However, since most of the PDs hitherto developed are implemented on rigid substrates,
(5−7)
their applications are highly restricted. Mechanically flexible infrared PDs can overcome these limitations through the capability to adjust the curvature and geometries on different demands.
(8,9)
This will enable ultrathin and lightweight design, excellent implantability, and convenient portability, making them suitable for next-generation thermographic imaging sensors that can be incorporated for biomedical sensing and wearable health monitoring devices.
(10−14)

Organic-based semiconducting materials have been extensively studied for flexible PDs due to their intrinsic material property. However, organic-based PDs still showed lower efficiency, inferior reliability, and slow operation speed compared to inorganic semiconductor-based PDs.
(8,15−17)
In contrast, epitaxial lift-off (ELO) of III–V compound semiconductor thin films enabled flexible and reliable optoelectronic devices such as flexible GaAs solar cells and lasers.
(18,19)
To date, previous flexible III–V PD works have been performed for only “visible” and “near-infrared” wavelengths using the lattice-matched GaAs/AlAs on GaAs wafer or InGaAs/InAlAs on InP wafer,
(14,20)
but no studies have been reported in the mid-wavelength (3–5 μm) infrared spectral region mainly due to the difficulties of heteroepitaxial growth and ELO process of low-band-gap materials. For example, the heteroepitaxial growth of InAs (
E
g
= 0.36 eV) or InSb (
E
g
= 0.17 eV) on GaAs suffers from the extremely large lattice mismatch to GaAs, ∼7.2 and 14.6%, and this results in high threading dislocation density (TDD). Therefore, the growth of sophisticated buffer layers to reduce the TDD needs to be done for maintaining high performance while simultaneously allowing the ELO process via HF solution for flexible infrared III–V-based PD arrays for various emerging applications.
(21−24)

In this work, we demonstrate high-detectivity flexible InAs thin-film photodetector arrays via metal wafer bonding and a high-throughput epitaxial lift-off process. An abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer structure was introduced to overcome the large lattice mismatch and to enable a smooth InAs etching interface after the ELO process. The novel InAlAs buffer was also crucial to reduce the TDD by a factor of 2. The flexible devices showed no performance degradation after a 1000 × bending test, proving their high mechanical robustness and reliability. Also, we demonstrate that flexible photodetectors can operate at room temperature without separate cooling systems, with a peak specific detectivity of 1.21 × 10
9
cm-Hz
1/2
/W at 3.4 μm, which is comparable to a commercial InAs photodetector. Flexible InAs photodetectors with these features in the mid-infrared wavelength will play an important role in the emerging biomedical thermal imaging and wearable health monitoring applications.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The schematic diagram in
Figure 1
a illustrates the heteroepitaxial lattice-mismatched InAs device structure on the GaAs substrate. In contrast to the GaAs/AlAs/GaAs ELO structure, an In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer was needed to bridge the large lattice mismatch (∼7.2%) between InAs and GaAs as well as to reduce the TDD in the InAs device layer.
(22)
Sample A was grown with a typical linearly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer on an AlAs sacrificial layer as shown in
Figure 1
b. We have increased the In flux from 0.1 to 1.8 Å/s, while the Al flux was decreased from 1.8 to 0.1 Å/s simultaneously. Etching the AlAs sacrificial layer was tested using the HF-based solution, and it was found that the linearly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer was only partially etched and the interface of the InAs/InAlAs layers was quite uneven as shown in
Figure 1
c. This is not acceptable for highly performing PD fabrication because the inhomogeneous thickness of the ELO InAs thin film would have unpredictable device performance with a different infrared absorption depth. To address this issue, an abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer was introduced for Sample B by varying the composition of the graded buffer layer as shown in
Figure 1
b. In contrast to the linear grading, a newly optimized abrupt In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer was grown carefully by increasing the In flux from 0.1 to 1.8 Å/s while the Al flux was fixed at a low growth rate of 0.1 Å/s.
Figure 1
c shows the smooth surface morphology of the etched surface after the ELO process, which reveals the absence of the dome-shaped profile.

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic of lattice-mismatched InAs-based device structure with In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer. (b) Lattice mismatch over epi thickness for two different epitaxial lift-off samples. Mismatches for In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer are drawn approximately. (c) Optical microscope images of Sample A (with linearly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer) and Sample B (with abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer) after the epitaxial lift-off process.

div.div:
Figure 2
a shows the entire sample structure of InAs PD grown on In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer/AlAs sacrificial layer on GaAs. Before the growth of the InAs PD active layer, we first desorbed the GaAs substrate at 540 °C for 10 min under As
2
overpressure to remove native oxide. Following oxide desorption, the 50 nm GaAs and AlAs sacrificial layers were grown at 580 °C. Then, the sample was cooled down to 420 °C for growth of 175 nm linearly and abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer layers. A relatively low growth temperature was chosen to prevent phase separation issues in the In
x
Al
1–
x
As ternary alloy and to achieve a smooth surface morphology. A 550 nm InAs buffer layer was grown on In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer layer. To further decrease TDD, a 200 nm tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As defect filter layer (DFL) was inserted prior to the InAs cap layer. Subsequently, the InAs p–i–n PD layer was grown.
Figure 2
b shows a 10 × 10 μm
2
atomic force microscope image showing the surface morphology of Sample B. Despite the large lattice mismatch between InAs and GaAs, the root-mean-square surface roughness of the InAs surface is merely 0.36 nm. The low surface roughness is crucial for metal wafer bonding and a high device yield after the ELO process. The cross-sectional transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image in
Figure 2
c was used to examine the evolution of misfit and threading dislocations in the metamorphic InAs epitaxial layer. As shown in the TEM image, high-density misfit and threading dislocations were generated in the In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer layer due to abrupt changes in lattice constant, and these dislocations were mostly confined to the graded buffer layer. Then, the remaining dislocations were additionally filtered out of the tensile-strained In
0.95
Al
0.05
As DFL, and the upper InAs active layer shows only a few TDs from the cross-sectional TEM image. The inset in
Figure 2
c reveals that the heteroepitaxial InAs layer is single crystalline. A closer inspection was carried out at the In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer/AlAs interface, and
Figure 2
d reveals an extremely high density of misfit dislocations in the abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer, indicating a high efficacy of TDD reduction. High-resolution phase-contrast TEM imaging shows a strong strain field around the misfit dislocation at the n-InAs buffer and the n-InAlAs DFL. See the
Supporting Information
for more details.
Figure 2
e shows the line-scan result of energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy over the InAs/InAlAs/AlAs/GaAs heterointerfaces. One can clearly observe the abrupt composition change between the AlAs sacrificial layer and the In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer. Jandl et al. reported that increasing the initial misfit in the InAs
x
P
1–
x
compositionally graded buffers on InP substrates was effective in reducing the tilt, surface roughness, and TDD.
(25)
We also believe that an analogous effect took place in our abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As that contributed to the high-quality InAs epitaxial layer. Electron channeling contrast imaging (ECCI) was used to quantitatively analyze the TDD on the InAs surface.
(26)
Figure 2
f shows an exemplary ECCI image with two TDs that were not filtered out by the In
0.95
Al
0.05
As DFL. We achieved TDDs of 3.9 × 10
7
and 2.1 × 10
7
cm
–2
for Samples A and B, respectively, after surveying more than 40 μm
2
each. In our previous study, we learned that a low TDD InAs metamorphic layer can be obtained by avoiding both phase separation and 3D islanding growth in the In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer.
(22)
Furthermore, we found out from this experiment that the TDD of Sample B was lower than that of Sample A by 46%, indicating that the abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer was more effective in filtering TDs than the linear grading buffer (see the
Supporting Information
). We compared our low TDD values with previously reported studies (
Figure 2
g), showing that Sample B is 5 × lower than the previously lowest TDD.
(21,23,24,27,28)
This record-low TDD value was achieved using both the well-optimized In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer and DFL.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Schematic diagram of the InAs p–i–n PD with optimal In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer layer grown on semi-insulating GaAs. (b) Surface morphology obtained by atomic force microscopy images of the InAs surface. (c) Cross-sectional bright-field TEM image of Sample B. The inset shows the selected area diffraction pattern. (d) TEM image at the interfaces between InAs buffer, In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer, AlAs sacrificial layer, and GaAs wafer. (e) Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy line profile on the red line in (d). (f) ECCI image of the InAs layer grown on GaAs. (g) Comparison of threading dislocation densities in InAs/GaAs materials reported by other groups.
(21,23,24,27,28)

div.div:
Figure 3
a shows the fabrication procedure of our flexible InAs PD arrays. Standard photolithography was used to define 20 × 10 mesa arrays. The unit device size was 400 × 400 μm
2
. During chemical etching, the mesas were etched down to expose the AlAs sacrificial layer.
(18)
Pt/Au (10/50 nm) was deposited as the bonding material and p-type Ohmic contact. After metal wafer bonding, the InAs epitaxial layer was separated from the GaAs donor substrate by the ELO process in an HF/acetone (1:1) solution. The TD-rich buffer was then etched before the deposition of the top contact. Finally, the flexible device was peeled from the Si handle substrate. A more detailed methodology can be found in the
Supporting Information
.
Figure 3
b shows a schematic illustration of the flexible InAs PD arrays in an exploded view.
Figure 3
c shows an optical image of the flexible device peeled off from the Si handle substrate and attached to a cylinder with a 5 mm radius of curvature.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) General procedure for the fabrication of flexible InAs PD. (b) Schematic illustration of the flexible InAs PD with the laminate process. (c) Photograph of a flexible InAs PD array in a bent state.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
We have measured the electrical and optical properties of the flexible PDs, and
Figure 4
a shows the dark and photocurrent density for the as-grown and flexible PDs. The devices show respective dark current densities of 1.1 and 0.98 mA/cm
2
at 0 V bias. The comparable dark current densities between the two PDs suggest that the ELO process did not degrade the material quality. In addition, the responsivity of PDs was defined as
(1)
where
R
is the responsivity,
I
ph
is the photocurrent,
I
dark
is the dark current, and
P
laser
is the laser power. The responsivities at 2 μm measured at 0 V bias (photovoltaic mode) are 0.43 and 0.41 A/W for the as-grown and flexible PD, respectively. This result again emphasizes the fact that no additional defects or cracks were formed during the ELO process. The laser power dependence of the photocurrent, which contains information on the trap state and photocurrent generation mechanism,
(14,29,30)
is shown in
Figure 4
b. The photocurrents at the 0 V bias increase linearly with the laser power density. We fitted the data according to the power law
(2)
where
A
is a parameter related to the responsivity of the PD and
P
is the laser power density. The fitting parameter α of our flexible device is 1.08.
Figure 4
c shows the dark
I
–
V
curves of 20 PD arrays under reverse bias. Highly uniform device quality was confirmed by the low dark current densities. The PD performance uniformity was also investigated at 0 V bias; see the
Supporting Information
for more details.
Figure 4
d shows the time-resolved photoresponse behavior of our flexible InAs detector under 2 μm infrared illumination with an optical power of 1.7 mW. As the light source was modulated, the device was switched at a high speed, and good repeatability and stability were also confirmed. The time required to increase photocurrent from 10 to 90% is defined as the rise time, and vice versa is defined as the decay time. As can be seen in
Figure 4
e,f, the rise and fall times are 1.31 μs and 585 ns, respectively. For reference, homoepitaxially grown InAs PD commercialized by Hamamatsu has a rise time of 0.7 μs.
(31)
The switching speed could be further improved through surface passivation, high-speed electrode design, and optimized thickness of p–i–n layer thickness.
(32,33)
We believe that the measured rise and fall times achieved by the high-quality InAs ELO process are fast enough to be used for potential applications for implanted biomedical applications and health monitoring systems. The flexible InAs PD arrays that perform reliably under different bending curvatures make them suitable for an imaging system with a superior field of view. To test the mechanical flexibility and stability of the PD arrays, we measured the dark and photocurrents under different bending conditions. The current–voltage characteristics were measured using an HP-4156C semiconductor parameter analyzer. The normalized dark current and photocurrent were measured by bending the device in a metal chuck with various curvatures (up to 1/
R
= 2 cm
-1
).
Figure 5
a shows the normalized dark current and photocurrent measured by bending the device on a metal chuck with various curvatures (see the
Supporting Information
). Both dark current and photocurrent did not change even at a high curvature of 2 cm
–1
. The slight variation in the values under different bending curvatures can be attributed to the measurement uncertainties.
Figure 5
b shows normalized dark and photocurrents during successive bending cycles. Even after the 1000 × bending cycle, the device still possessed almost the same current values. Both these tests demonstrate the high mechanical robustness of our flexible InAs PD arrays.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Dark current and photocurrent comparison of as-grown and flexible InAs PDs. (b) Photocurrent of flexible InAs PD dependent on laser power density. The inset shows the relationship between the laser power density and photocurrent. (c) Dark
I
–
V
curve of 20 PD arrays under reverse bias. (d) Dynamic photocurrent behavior. (e, f) Rise and decay times of the device (10–90%).
Figure 5. (a) Normalized dark current and photocurrent at different bending curvatures. (b) Flexible InAs PD durability test by repeating device bending up to 1000 times.

div.div:
Finally, the spectral photoresponse of flexible InAs PD was investigated using a Bruker Vertex 80v Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscope at atmospheric pressure. To obtain the absolute value of responsivity, the measured spectral response was calibrated by achieving the peak responsivity of our PD with a blackbody source at 500 K (
Figure 6
a).
(34)
Figure 6
b shows that the peak responsivity of the flexible InAs PD was 0.70 A/W at 3.4 μm. The spectral responsivity at 2 μm was measured lower than those measured by the 2 μm laser source, indicating that our InAs PDs have power-dependent photoresponsivity (see the
Supporting Information
). In addition, several resonant peaks were observed in the spectral responsivity of the flexible PD, which were positioned at around 2.85 and 3.4 μm. We think that it is due to the micro-cavity effect in the two mirrors of Pt/Au bonding material and InAs/air interface.
(14,35,36)
Figure 6
c shows the noise current level of the flexible device. The specific detectivity of flexible InAs PD is defined as
(3)
where
A
is the window size of the device, Δ
f
is the bandwidth, and
i
n
is the noise current of the device.
Figure 6
d shows the bias-dependent specific detectivity of the flexible InAs PD at room temperature. The peak detectivity of our flexible InAs PD showed 1.21 × 10
9
cm-Hz
1/2
/W at a 0 V bias. Note that a commercial InAs PD from Hamamatsu shows 4.5 × 10
9
cm-Hz
1/2
/W at 3.35 μm. We expect that the detectivity of our flexible PD could be further improved by applying proper antireflection coatings. To investigate the optical micro-cavity effect due to the metal stacks, we used Lumerical finite-difference-time-domain (FDTD) software and simulated the absorbance spectrum of our InAs PD with and without metal stacks.
Figure 6
e shows that the metal stack can selectively enhance the absorbance at certain wavelengths. Notably, at around 2.8 and 3.4 μm, the Fabry–Perot effect due to the metal stack can enhance the absorbance by 147 and 296%, respectively. These peaks, as well as their free spectral range (∼0.6 μm), are consistent with our photoresponse data (
Figure 6
b).
Figure 6
f shows the electrical field intensity profile in the active layer as a function of incident light wavelength. Across the entire range of wavelengths surveyed, the photons are not completely absorbed by the InAs active layer. Transmitted photons reach the bottom and are reflected by the metal stack, which enhance the responsivity of the PD through the micro-cavity effect. Considering that the reflectance of Pt/Au is about 80% in the mid-infrared region, the responsivity can be further improved by controlling the cavity length and structure for an efficient cavity effect. Furthermore, the air/InAs interface reflects 30–42% of normal-incident mid-infrared light; hence, the responsivity can be significantly improved by incorporating an antireflection coating.
Table 1
compares our result to the various InAs PDs reported by other groups.
(28,31,37,38)
This work not only shows the first flexible InAs mid-wavelength infrared PD arrays but also reveals the highest specific detectivity among the heteroepitaxially grown InAs PDs. For future work, further optimization of In
0.95
Al
0..5
As DFLs and the structure for efficient cavity effect will be done to further improve the PD performance.

div.p: Figure 6. (a) Schematic view of the measurement system with a blackbody source for calibration. The chopper frequency was 462 Hz. (b) Calibrated spectral responsivity of the flexible device measured by the FTIR system at 300 K under atmospheric pressure. (c) Noise current level of the flexible InAs PD. (d) Bias-dependent peak detectivity of the flexible InAs PD at 300 K. (e) Calculated power absorbance in the InAs active layers over wavelength. (f) Electric field intensity distribution of the InAs PD with wafer bonding metal stack.

div.div:
Table 1. Comparison of InAs p–i–n PDs Grown on Various Wafers
a

div.p: Our flexible PD shows the highest specific detectivity among the other heteroepitaxial InAs PDs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In conclusion, we demonstrate high-performance flexible InAs PD arrays grown on a GaAs substrate then transferred to a flexible substrate through metal wafer bonding and epitaxial lift-off. We found out that the novel abruptly graded In
x
Al
1–
x
As buffer layer not only lowered threading dislocation density to 2.1 × 10
7
cm
–2
effectively but also enabled smooth epitaxial lift-off surface. The flexible InAs photodetector was switched at a very high speed with rise and fall times of 1.31 and 0.58 μs, respectively, and showed excellent mechanical robustness without any performance degradation under various curvatures and repeated bending test. The flexible PD arrays also exhibited high responsivity from 1.5 to 3.7 μm, with a peak specific detectivity of 1.21 × 10
9
cm-Hz
1/2
/W at 3.4 μm. This work shows that flexible InAs PD arrays enabled by epitaxial lift-off are promising for next-generation emerging biomedical thermal imaging and wearable health monitoring applications.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The sample structure is shown in
Figure 2
a. All samples studied here were grown in a Veeco GEN-930 molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) machine equipped with arsenic (As) cracker cell. The GaAs substrate was first desorbed at 540 °C for 10 min under As
2
overpressure to remove native oxide on the surface. After oxide desorption, the 50 nm GaAs buffer layer was grown at 580 °C, followed by a 50 nm AlAs sacrificial layer for the epitaxial lift-off process. Then, the sample was cooled down to 420 °C for the growth of 175 nm linearly and abruptly n-In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer layers. In contrast to linear grading, a newly optimized abrupt In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer was grown carefully by increasing the In flux from 0.1 to 1.8 Å/s while the Al flux was fixed at a low growth rate of 0.1 Å/s. A relatively low growth temperature was chosen to prevent the phase separation issues in the In
x
Al
1–
x
As ternary alloy and to achieve a smooth surface. Subsequently, a 550 nm n-InAs buffer layer was grown on the In
x
Al
1–
x
As graded buffer layer. To further decrease TDD, a 200 nm tensile-strained n-In
0.95
Al
0.05
As defect filter layer (DFL) was inserted prior to the InAs cap layer. Subsequently, the InAs p–i–n PD layer was grown. Si and Be cells were used as n-type and p-type dopants, and the n-type and p-type doping concentrations are 5 × 10
16
and 5 × 10
18
cm
–2
, respectively.

The spectral photoresponse of a flexible InAs photodetector was measured using a Bruker Vertex 80v Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy system at atmospheric pressure. The measured samples were wire-bonded on standard 16 dual in-line package and then mounted in an Optistat DN-V cryostat. A Stanford Research SR 570 low-noise current preamplifier was used to amplify the resultant photoresponse signal. The output interferogram signal was processed by a Bruker digitizer and recorded by OPUS readout software. A Stanford Research Systems SR760 Fast-Fourier transform spectrum analyzer was used to measure the noise density of the flexible InAs photodetector. Lumerical finite-difference-time-domain software was used to simulate the absorbance spectrum of our samples with and without metal stacks.

Guan, Xinwei; Yu, Xuechao; Periyanagounder, Dharmaraj; Benzigar, Mercy Rose; Huang, Jing-Kai; Lin, Chun-Ho; Kim, Jiyun; Singh, Simrjit; Hu, Long; Liu, Guozhen; Li, Dehui; He, Jr-Hau; Yan, Feng; Wang, Qi Jie; Wu, Tom

A review. The extraordinary electronic, optical, and mech. characteristics of 2D materials make them promising candidates for optoelectronics, specifically in IR (IR) detectors owing to their flexible compn. and tunable optoelectronic properties. This review presents the recent progress in IR detectors composed of 2D materials and their hybrid structures, including graphene, black phosphorus, transition metal dichalcogenides, halide perovskite as well as other new layered materials and their heterostructures. The focus is on the short-wave, mid-wave, and long-wave IR regimes, which pose a grand challenge for rational materials and device designs. The dependence of the device performance on the optical and electronic properties of 2D materials is extensively discussed, aiming to present the general strategies for designing optoelectronic devices with optimal performance. Furthermore, the recent results on 2D material-based heterostructures are presented with an emphasis on the relationship between band alignment, charge transfer, and IR photodetection. Finally, a summary is given as well as the discussion of existing challenges and future directions.

Kenry; Yeo, Joo Chuan; Lim, Chwee Teck

There are now numerous emerging flexible and wearable sensing technologies that can perform a myriad of phys. and physiol. measurements. Rapid advances in developing and implementing such sensors in the last several years have demonstrated the growing significance and potential utility of this unique class of sensing platforms. Applications include wearable consumer electronics, soft robotics, medical prosthetics, electronic skin, and health monitoring. In this review, we provide a state-of-the-art overview of the emerging flexible and wearable sensing platforms for healthcare and biomedical applications. We first introduce the selection of flexible and stretchable materials and the fabrication of sensors based on these materials. We then compare the different solid-state and liq.-state phys. sensing platforms and examine the mech. deformation-based working mechanisms of these sensors. We also highlight some of the exciting applications of flexible and wearable phys. sensors in emerging healthcare and biomedical applications, in particular for artificial electronic skins, physiol. health monitoring and assessment, and therapeutic and drug delivery. Finally, we conclude this review by offering some insight into the challenges and opportunities facing this field.

Flexible sensing devices have gained a great deal of attention among the scientific community in recent years. The application of flexible sensors spans over several fields, including medicine, industrial automation, robotics, security, and human-machine interfacing. In particular, non-invasive health-monitoring devices are expected to play a key role in the improvement of patient life and in reducing costs assocd. with clin. and biomedical diagnostic procedures. Here, we focus on recent advances achieved in flexible devices applied on the human skin for biomedical and healthcare purposes.

Flexible image sensors have attracted increasing attention as new imaging devices owing to their lightness, softness, and bendability. Since light can measure inside information from outside of the body, optical-imaging-based approaches, such as X-rays, are widely used for disease diagnosis in hospitals. Unlike conventional sensors, flexible image sensors are soft and can be directly attached to a curved surface, such as the skin, for continuous measurement of biometric information with high accuracy. Therefore, they are expected to gain wide application to wearable devices, as well as home medical care. Herein, the application of such sensors to the biomedical field is introduced. First, their individual components, photosensors, and switching elements, are explained. Then, the basic parameters used to evaluate the performance of each of these elements and the image sensors are described. Finally, examples of measuring the dynamic and static biometric information using flexible image sensors, together with relevant real-world measurement cases, are presented. Furthermore, recent applications of the flexible image sensors in the biomedical field are introduced.

Investigations of antimonide-based materials began at about the same time as HgCdTe ternary alloys-in the 1950s, and the apparent rapid success of their technol., esp. low-dimensional solids, depends on the previous five decades of III-V materials and device research. However, the sophisticated physics assocd. with the antimonide-based bandgap engineering concept started at the beginning of 1990s gave a new impact and interest in development of IR detector structures within academic and national labs. The development of InAs/GaSb type-II superlattices (T2SLs) results from two primary motivations: the perceived challenges of reproducibly fabricating high-operability HgCdTe focal plane arrays (FPAs) at reasonable cost and the theor. predictions of lower Auger recombination for type T2SL detectors compared with HgCdTe. Second motivation-lower Auger recombination should be translated into a fundamental advantage for T2SL over HgCdTe in terms of lower dark current and/or higher operating temp., provided other parameters such as Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) lifetime are equal. InAs/GaSb T2SL photodetectors offer similar performance to HgCdTe at an equiv. cut-off wavelength, but with a sizeable penalty in operating temp., due to the inherent difference in SRH lifetimes. It is predicted that since the future IR (IR) systems will be based on the room temp. operation of depletion-current limited arrays with pixel densities that are fully consistent with background- and diffraction-limited performance due to the system optics, the material system with long SRH lifetime will be required. Since T2SLs are very much resisted in attempts to improve its SRH lifetime, currently the only material that meets this requirement is HgCdTe. Due to less ionic chem. bonding, III-V semiconductors are more robust than their II-VI counterparts. As a result, III-V-based FPAs excel in operability, spatial uniformity, temporal stability, scalability, producibility, and affordability-the so-called "ibility" advantages. Soibel, Alexander; Hill, Cory J.; Keo, Sam A.; Hoglund, Linda; Rosenberg, Robert; Kowalczyk, Robert; Khoshakhlagh, Arezou; Fisher, Anita; Ting, David Z.-Y.; Gunapala, Sarath D.

In this work, we investigate the high temp. performance of mid-wavelength IR InAsSb-AlAsSb nBn detectors with cut-off wavelengths near 4.5 μm. The quantum efficiency of these devices is 35% without antireflection coatings and does not change with temp. in the 77-325 K temp. range, indicating potential for room temp. operation. The current generation of nBn detectors shows an increase of operational bias with temp., which is attributed to a shift in the Fermi energy level in the absorber. Anal. of the device performance shows that operational bias and quantum efficiency of these detectors can be further improved. The device dark current stays diffusion limited in the 150 K-325 K temp. range and becomes dominated by generation-recombination processes at lower temps. Detector detectivities are D*(λ) = 1 × 109 (cm Hz0.5/W) at T = 300 K and D*(λ) = 5 × 109 (cm Hz0.5/W) at T = 250 K, which is easily achievable with a one stage TE cooler. A review. This article reviews the history, the present status and possible future developments of HgCdTe ternary alloy for IR detector applications. HgCdTe IR detectors have been intensively developed since the first synthesis of this material in 1958. This article summarizes the fundamental properties of this versatile narrow gap semiconductor, and relates the material properties to its successful applications as an IR photoconductive and photovoltaic detector material. An emphasis is put on key developments in the crystal growth and their influence on device evolution. Competitive technologies to HgCdTe ternary alloy are also presented. Recent advances of backside illuminated HgCdTe heterojunction photodiodes have enabled a third generation of multispectral instruments for remote sensing applications and have led to the practicality of multiband IR focal plane array technol. Finally, evaluation of HgCdTe for room temp. long wavelength IR applications is presented.

IR chem. imaging is a rapidly emerging field with new advances in instrumentation, data acquisition and data anal. These developments have had significant impact in biomedical applications and numerous studies have now shown that this technol. offers great promise for the improved diagnosis of the diseased state. Relying on purely biochem. signatures rather than contrast from exogenous dyes and stains, IR chem. imaging has the potential to revolutionise histopathol. for improved disease diagnosis. In this review we discuss the recent advances in IR spectroscopic imaging specifically related to spectral histopathol. (SHP) and consider the current state of the field. Finally we consider the practical application of SHP for disease diagnosis and consider potential barriers to clin. translation highlighting current directions and the future outlook.

We demonstrate flexible GaAs photodetector arrays that were hetero-epitaxially grown on a Si wafer for a new cost-effective and reliable wearable optoelectronics platform. A high cryst. quality GaAs layer was transferred onto a flexible foreign substrate and excellent retention of device performance was demonstrated by measuring the optical responsivities and dark currents. Optical simulation proves that the metal stacks used for wafer bonding serve as a back-reflector and enhance GaAs photodetector responsivity via a resonant-cavity effect. Device durability was also tested by bending 1000 times and no performance degrdn. was obsd. This work paves a way for a cost-effective and flexible III-V optoelectronics technol. with high durability.

Org. photodetectors are interesting for low cost, large area optical sensing applications. Combining org. semiconductors with discrete absorption bands outside the visible wavelength range with transparent and conductive electrodes allows for the fabrication of visibly transparent photodetectors. Visibly transparent photodetectors can have far reaching impact in a no. of areas including smart displays, window-integrated electronic circuits and sensors. Here, we demonstrate a near-IR sensitive, visibly transparent org. photodetector with a very high av. visible transmittance of 68.9%. The transmitted light of the photodetector under solar irradn. exhibits excellent transparency color perception and rendering capabilities. At a wavelength of 850 nm and at -1 V bias, the photoconversion efficiency is 17% and the specific detectivity is 1012 Jones. Large area photodetectors with an area of 1.6 cm2 are demonstrated.

(small mols. and polymers) heterojunction are prepd. Primarily, the photodetector shows a broadband photoresponse from 365 to 10600 nm. Si-based integrated circuits have been intensively developed over the past several decades through ultimate device scaling. However, the Si technol. has reached the phys. limitations of the scaling. These limitations have fuelled the search for alternative active materials (for transistors) and the introduction of optical interconnects (called "Si photonics"). A series of attempts to circumvent the Si technol. limits are based on the use of III-V compd. semiconductor due to their superior benefits, such as high electron mobility and direct bandgap. To use their phys. properties on a Si platform, the formation of high-quality III-V films on the Si (III-V/Si) is the basic technol. ; however, implementing this technol. using a high-throughput process is not easy. Here, we report new concepts for an ultra-high-throughput heterogeneous integration of high-quality III-V films on the Si using the wafer bonding and epitaxial lift off (ELO) technique. We describe the ultra-fast ELO and also the re-use of the III-V donor wafer after III-V/Si formation. These approaches provide an ultra-high-throughput fabrication of III-V/Si substrates with a high-quality film, which leads to a dramatic cost redn. As proof-of-concept devices, this paper demonstrates GaAs-based high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs), solar cells, and hetero-junction phototransistors on Si substrates.

Lightwt., flexible solar cells from III-V semiconductors offer new application opportunities for devices that require a power supply, such as cars, drones, satellites, or wearable devices, due to their outstanding efficiency and power-to-wt. ratio (specific power). However, the specific power and stability of flexible photovoltaic (PV) devices need to be enhanced for use in such applications because current flexible PV devices are vulnerable to moisture and heat. Here, we develop ultra-lightwt., flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer that serves as both a moisture barrier and an antireflection coating for the active device layer. Using a thin polymer film as a substrate and an ultrathin metal as a bonding layer, the total wt. of the device is dramatically reduced. Therefore, the specific power of our solar cells is remarkably high with a value of over 5000 W/kg under the AM 1.5G solar spectrum. Addnl., there is no degrdn. even if the solar cells are exposed to harsh environmental conditions.

Natural imaging systems such as the retina and the compd. eye employ a conformal architecture that provides an aberration-free image with wide field of view (FOV) and very low f/no. However, most artificial imagers such as conventional cameras are limited to a planar architecture demanded by the use of brittle semiconductor focal plane arrays (FPAs). High-resoln. image formation on this flat field requires multiple bulky optical elements. Here we demonstrate a general approach to fabricating complex circuits and in particular FPAs on flexible and/or conformable substrates that can be shaped to overcome these fundamental limitations. An 8 × 100, lightwt., thin-film In0.53Ga0.47As p-i-n photodiode FPA with sensitivity to wavelengths as long as λ = 1650 nm is fabricated on a thin flexible plastic foil following transfer by adhesive-free bonding of the epitaxial layers that are subsequently lifted off from the parent InP substrate. The array is shaped into either a convex cylindrically curved imager to achieve a 2π FOV or, when formed into a concave shape, to provide high-resoln. and compact spectral decompn. over a wide wavelength range. The array exhibits ∼99% fabrication yield with ∼100% peak external quantum efficiency at λ = 1300 nm. The unique features of this flexible thin-film FPA provide a new paradigm for realizing advanced electronic and imaging applications.

Strain relaxation processes in InAs heteroepitaxy have been studied. While InAs grows in a layer-by-layer mode on lattice-mismatched substrates of GaAs(111)A, Si(111), and GaSb(111)A, the strain relaxation process strongly depends on the lattice mismatch. The d. of threading defects in the InAs film increases with lattice mismatch. We found that the peak width in x-ray diffraction is insensitive to the defect d., but critically depends on the residual lattice strain in InAs films.

Due to the excellent elec. transport properties and optoelectronic performance, thin indium selenide (InSe) has recently attracted attention in the field of 2D semiconducting materials. However, the mechanism behind the photocurrent generation in thin InSe photodetectors remains elusive. Here, we present a set of expts. aimed at explaining the strong scattering in the photoresponsivity values reported in the literature for thin InSe photodetectors. By performing optoelectronic measurements on thin InSe-based photodetectors operated under different environmental conditions we find that the photoresponsivity, the response time and the photocurrent power dependency are strongly correlated in this material. This observation indicates that the photogating effect plays an imporant role in thin InSe flakes, and it is the dominant mechanism in the ultra-high photoresponsivity of pristine InSe devices. In addn., when exposing the pristine InSe photodetectors to the ambient environment we observe a fast and irreversible change in the photoresponse, with a decrease in the photoresponsivity accompanied by an increase of the operating speed. We attribute this photodetector performance change (upon atm. exposure) to the decrease in the d. of the traps present in InSe, due to the passivation of selenium vacancies by atm. oxygen species. This passivation is accompanied by a downward shift of the InSe Fermi level and by a decrease of the Fermi level pinning, which leads to an increase of the Schottky barrier between Au and InSe. Our study reveals the important role of traps induced by defects in tailoring the properties of devices based on 2D materials and offers a controllable route to design and functionalize thin InSe photodetectors to realize devices with either ultrahigh photoresposivity or fast operation speed.

The grating coupled GaAs/AlGaAs quantum well IR photodetectors (QWIPs) are integrated onto Si substrates using metal wafer bonding and epitaxial lift-off process. We report a mid-IR InAs p-i-n photovoltaic detector on a Si substrate operating at room temp. with a cutoff wavelength at 3.5 μm. The large 11.6% lattice mismatch between the device layer (InAs) and the Si substrate is accommodated by employing a compositionally graded buffer layer technique using solid-source mol. beam epitaxy and a com. available GeSi substrate. An AlxIn1-xAs graded buffer layer is used to linearly scale the lattice const. from AlAs to InAs with an increasing x value. The photovoltaic detector has a responsivity of 0.57 A/W, measured using a blackbody source maintained at 700 °C.

Recent Progress in Short- to Long-Wave Infrared Photodetection Using 2D Materials and Heterostructures
Guan, Xinwei; Yu, Xuechao; Periyanagounder, Dharmaraj; Benzigar, Mercy Rose; Huang, Jing-Kai; Lin, Chun-Ho; Kim, Jiyun; Singh, Simrjit; Hu, Long; Liu, Guozhen; Li, Dehui; He, Jr-Hau; Yan, Feng; Wang, Qi Jie; Wu, Tom

A review. The extraordinary electronic, optical, and mech. characteristics of 2D materials make them promising candidates for optoelectronics, specifically in IR (IR) detectors owing to their flexible compn. and tunable optoelectronic properties. This review presents the recent progress in IR detectors composed of 2D materials and their hybrid structures, including graphene, black phosphorus, transition metal dichalcogenides, halide perovskite as well as other new layered materials and their heterostructures. The focus is on the short-wave, mid-wave, and long-wave IR regimes, which pose a grand challenge for rational materials and device designs. The dependence of the device performance on the optical and electronic properties of 2D materials is extensively discussed, aiming to present the general strategies for designing optoelectronic devices with optimal performance. Furthermore, the recent results on 2D material-based heterostructures are presented with an emphasis on the relationship between band alignment, charge transfer, and IR photodetection. Finally, a summary is given as well as the discussion of existing challenges and future directions.

There are now numerous emerging flexible and wearable sensing technologies that can perform a myriad of phys. and physiol. measurements. Rapid advances in developing and implementing such sensors in the last several years have demonstrated the growing significance and potential utility of this unique class of sensing platforms. Applications include wearable consumer electronics, soft robotics, medical prosthetics, electronic skin, and health monitoring. In this review, we provide a state-of-the-art overview of the emerging flexible and wearable sensing platforms for healthcare and biomedical applications. We first introduce the selection of flexible and stretchable materials and the fabrication of sensors based on these materials. We then compare the different solid-state and liq.-state phys. sensing platforms and examine the mech. deformation-based working mechanisms of these sensors. We also highlight some of the exciting applications of flexible and wearable phys. sensors in emerging healthcare and biomedical applications, in particular for artificial electronic skins, physiol. health monitoring and assessment, and therapeutic and drug delivery. Finally, we conclude this review by offering some insight into the challenges and opportunities facing this field.

Flexible image sensors have attracted increasing attention as new imaging devices owing to their lightness, softness, and bendability. Since light can measure inside information from outside of the body, optical-imaging-based approaches, such as X-rays, are widely used for disease diagnosis in hospitals. Unlike conventional sensors, flexible image sensors are soft and can be directly attached to a curved surface, such as the skin, for continuous measurement of biometric information with high accuracy. Therefore, they are expected to gain wide application to wearable devices, as well as home medical care. Herein, the application of such sensors to the biomedical field is introduced. First, their individual components, photosensors, and switching elements, are explained. Then, the basic parameters used to evaluate the performance of each of these elements and the image sensors are described. Finally, examples of measuring the dynamic and static biometric information using flexible image sensors, together with relevant real-world measurement cases, are presented. Furthermore, recent applications of the flexible image sensors in the biomedical field are introduced.

Rogalski, A.; Martyniuk, P.; Kopytko, M.

Investigations of antimonide-based materials began at about the same time as HgCdTe ternary alloys-in the 1950s, and the apparent rapid success of their technol., esp. low-dimensional solids, depends on the previous five decades of III-V materials and device research. However, the sophisticated physics assocd. with the antimonide-based bandgap engineering concept started at the beginning of 1990s gave a new impact and interest in development of IR detector structures within academic and national labs. The development of InAs/GaSb type-II superlattices (T2SLs) results from two primary motivations: the perceived challenges of reproducibly fabricating high-operability HgCdTe focal plane arrays (FPAs) at reasonable cost and the theor. predictions of lower Auger recombination for type T2SL detectors compared with HgCdTe. Second motivation-lower Auger recombination should be translated into a fundamental advantage for T2SL over HgCdTe in terms of lower dark current and/or higher operating temp., provided other parameters such as Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) lifetime are equal. InAs/GaSb T2SL photodetectors offer similar performance to HgCdTe at an equiv. cut-off wavelength, but with a sizeable penalty in operating temp., due to the inherent difference in SRH lifetimes. It is predicted that since the future IR (IR) systems will be based on the room temp. operation of depletion-current limited arrays with pixel densities that are fully consistent with background- and diffraction-limited performance due to the system optics, the material system with long SRH lifetime will be required. Since T2SLs are very much resisted in attempts to improve its SRH lifetime, currently the only material that meets this requirement is HgCdTe. Due to less ionic chem. bonding, III-V semiconductors are more robust than their II-VI counterparts. As a result, III-V-based FPAs excel in operability, spatial uniformity, temporal stability, scalability, producibility, and affordability-the so-called "ibility" advantages. (c) 2017 American Institute of Physics.

In this work, we investigate the high temp. performance of mid-wavelength IR InAsSb-AlAsSb nBn detectors with cut-off wavelengths near 4.5 μm. The quantum efficiency of these devices is 35% without antireflection coatings and does not change with temp. in the 77-325 K temp. range, indicating potential for room temp. operation. The current generation of nBn detectors shows an increase of operational bias with temp., which is attributed to a shift in the Fermi energy level in the absorber. Anal. of the device performance shows that operational bias and quantum efficiency of these detectors can be further improved. The device dark current stays diffusion limited in the 150 K-325 K temp. range and becomes dominated by generation-recombination processes at lower temps. Detector detectivities are D*(λ) = 1 × 109 (cm Hz0.5/W) at T = 300 K and D*(λ) = 5 × 109 (cm Hz0.5/W) at T = 250 K, which is easily achievable with a one stage TE cooler. A review. This article reviews the history, the present status and possible future developments of HgCdTe ternary alloy for IR detector applications. HgCdTe IR detectors have been intensively developed since the first synthesis of this material in 1958. This article summarizes the fundamental properties of this versatile narrow gap semiconductor, and relates the material properties to its successful applications as an IR photoconductive and photovoltaic detector material. An emphasis is put on key developments in the crystal growth and their influence on device evolution. Competitive technologies to HgCdTe ternary alloy are also presented. Recent advances of backside illuminated HgCdTe heterojunction photodiodes have enabled a third generation of multispectral instruments for remote sensing applications and have led to the practicality of multiband IR focal plane array technol. Finally, evaluation of HgCdTe for room temp. long wavelength IR applications is presented.

IR chem. imaging is a rapidly emerging field with new advances in instrumentation, data acquisition and data anal. These developments have had significant impact in biomedical applications and numerous studies have now shown that this technol. offers great promise for the improved diagnosis of the diseased state. Relying on purely biochem. signatures rather than contrast from exogenous dyes and stains, IR chem. imaging has the potential to revolutionise histopathol. for improved disease diagnosis. In this review we discuss the recent advances in IR spectroscopic imaging specifically related to spectral histopathol. (SHP) and consider the current state of the field. Finally we consider the practical application of SHP for disease diagnosis and consider potential barriers to clin. translation highlighting current directions and the future outlook.

We demonstrate flexible GaAs photodetector arrays that were hetero-epitaxially grown on a Si wafer for a new cost-effective and reliable wearable optoelectronics platform. A high cryst. quality GaAs layer was transferred onto a flexible foreign substrate and excellent retention of device performance was demonstrated by measuring the optical responsivities and dark currents. Optical simulation proves that the metal stacks used for wafer bonding serve as a back-reflector and enhance GaAs photodetector responsivity via a resonant-cavity effect. Device durability was also tested by bending 1000 times and no performance degrdn. was obsd. This work paves a way for a cost-effective and flexible III-V optoelectronics technol. with high durability.

Org. photodetectors are interesting for low cost, large area optical sensing applications. Combining org. semiconductors with discrete absorption bands outside the visible wavelength range with transparent and conductive electrodes allows for the fabrication of visibly transparent photodetectors. Visibly transparent photodetectors can have far reaching impact in a no. of areas including smart displays, window-integrated electronic circuits and sensors. Here, we demonstrate a near-IR sensitive, visibly transparent org. photodetector with a very high av. visible transmittance of 68.9%. The transmitted light of the photodetector under solar irradn. exhibits excellent transparency color perception and rendering capabilities. At a wavelength of 850 nm and at -1 V bias, the photoconversion efficiency is 17% and the specific detectivity is 1012 Jones. Large area photodetectors with an area of 1.6 cm2 are demonstrated.

In this work, high-performance UV to long-wave IR (UV-LIR) devices based on an N-type three-dimensional (3D) Dirac semimetal Cd3As2 and P-type org. (small mols. and polymers) heterojunction are prepd. Primarily, the photodetector shows a broadband photoresponse from 365 to 10600 nm. The optimized device responsivity is 729 mA/W, along with a fast response time of 282 μs and a high on-off ratio of 6268, which are 2 orders of magnitude higher than those previously reported for a 3D Dirac semimetal-based device. In the LIR region (10600 nm), the responsivity and on-off ratio can reach 81.3 mA/W and 100, resp. In addn., the time-resolved femtosecond pump detection technol. is used to reveal the relaxation time of Cd3As2/org. thin films (4.30 ps), indicating that Cd3As2/org. thin films have great potential for the manuf. of fast IR devices. These results demonstrate that the 3D Dirac semimetal/org. thin film heterojunction photodetectors will be a feasible soln. for high-speed and broadband photodetectors in large-array imaging.

Ultra-high-throughput Production of III-V/Si Wafer for Electronic and Photonic Applications
Geum, Dae-Myeong; Park, Min-Su; Lim, Ju Young; Yang, Hyun-Duk; Song, Jin Dong; Kim, Chang Zoo; Yoon, Euijoon; Kim, SangHyeon; Choi, Won Jun

Si-based integrated circuits have been intensively developed over the past several decades through ultimate device scaling. However, the Si technol. has reached the phys. limitations of the scaling. These limitations have fuelled the search for alternative active materials (for transistors) and the introduction of optical interconnects (called "Si photonics"). A series of attempts to circumvent the Si technol. limits are based on the use of III-V compd. semiconductor due to their superior benefits, such as high electron mobility and direct bandgap. To use their phys. properties on a Si platform, the formation of high-quality III-V films on the Si (III-V/Si) is the basic technol. ; however, implementing this technol. using a high-throughput process is not easy. Here, we report new concepts for an ultra-high-throughput heterogeneous integration of high-quality III-V films on the Si using the wafer bonding and epitaxial lift off (ELO) technique. We describe the ultra-fast ELO and also the re-use of the III-V donor wafer after III-V/Si formation. These approaches provide an ultra-high-throughput fabrication of III-V/Si substrates with a high-quality film, which leads to a dramatic cost redn. As proof-of-concept devices, this paper demonstrates GaAs-based high electron mobility transistors (HEMTs), solar cells, and hetero-junction phototransistors on Si substrates.

Lightwt., flexible solar cells from III-V semiconductors offer new application opportunities for devices that require a power supply, such as cars, drones, satellites, or wearable devices, due to their outstanding efficiency and power-to-wt. ratio (specific power). However, the specific power and stability of flexible photovoltaic (PV) devices need to be enhanced for use in such applications because current flexible PV devices are vulnerable to moisture and heat. Here, we develop ultra-lightwt., flexible InGaP/GaAs tandem solar cells with a dual-function encapsulation layer that serves as both a moisture barrier and an antireflection coating for the active device layer. Using a thin polymer film as a substrate and an ultrathin metal as a bonding layer, the total wt. of the device is dramatically reduced. Therefore, the specific power of our solar cells is remarkably high with a value of over 5000 W/kg under the AM 1.5G solar spectrum. Addnl., there is no degrdn. even if the solar cells are exposed to harsh environmental conditions.

Natural imaging systems such as the retina and the compd. eye employ a conformal architecture that provides an aberration-free image with wide field of view (FOV) and very low f/no. However, most artificial imagers such as conventional cameras are limited to a planar architecture demanded by the use of brittle semiconductor focal plane arrays (FPAs). High-resoln. image formation on this flat field requires multiple bulky optical elements. Here we demonstrate a general approach to fabricating complex circuits and in particular FPAs on flexible and/or conformable substrates that can be shaped to overcome these fundamental limitations. An 8 × 100, lightwt., thin-film In0.53Ga0.47As p-i-n photodiode FPA with sensitivity to wavelengths as long as λ = 1650 nm is fabricated on a thin flexible plastic foil following transfer by adhesive-free bonding of the epitaxial layers that are subsequently lifted off from the parent InP substrate. The array is shaped into either a convex cylindrically curved imager to achieve a 2π FOV or, when formed into a concave shape, to provide high-resoln. and compact spectral decompn. over a wide wavelength range. The array exhibits ∼99% fabrication yield with ∼100% peak external quantum efficiency at λ = 1300 nm. The unique features of this flexible thin-film FPA provide a new paradigm for realizing advanced electronic and imaging applications.

Linearly graded InAlAs buffers were employed to bridge the high lattice mismatch between InAs and Si. Quant. measurement for threading dislocation d. (TDD) in the InAs layers grown on GaAs and Si has been performed using transmission electron microscopy and electron channeling contrast imaging, both of which revealed that the TDD of InAs/Si sample is ∼35% higher than that of GaAs sample. Comparison of fabricated InAs p-i-n photodetectors indicated that redn. of threading dislocation d. is crucial for low dark current and high responsivity mid-IR photodetectors on Si.

Strain relaxation processes in InAs heteroepitaxy have been studied. While InAs grows in a layer-by-layer mode on lattice-mismatched substrates of GaAs(111)A, Si(111), and GaSb(111)A, the strain relaxation process strongly depends on the lattice mismatch. We found that the peak width in x-ray diffraction is insensitive to the defect d., but critically depends on the residual lattice strain in InAs films.

The properties of InAsxP1-x compositionally graded buffers grown by metal org. chem. vapor deposition are investigated. We report the effects of strain gradient (ε/thickness), growth temp., and strain initiation sequence (gradual or abrupt strain introduction) on threading dislocation d., surface roughness, epi-layer relaxation, and tilt. A method of abrupt strain initiation is proposed which can result in dislocation densities as low as 1.01 × 105 cm-2 for films graded from the InP lattice const. to InAs0.15P0.85. Various types of dislocation filter layers and growth temps. of initial GaAs layer were investigated to reduce the threading dislocation densities in GaAs on GaP/Si. Electron channeling contrast imaging techniques revealed that an optimized GaAs buffer layer with thermal cycle annealing and InGaAs/GaAs dislocation filter layers has a threading dislocation d. of 7.2 × 106 cm-2, which is a factor of 40 lower than an unoptimized GaAs buffer. The root-mean-square surface roughness was greatly decreased from 7.8 nm to 2.9 nm after the optimization process. A strong enhancement in photoluminescence intensity indicates that the optimized GaAs template grown on on-axis (001) GaP/Si substrates is a promising virtual substrate for Si-based optoelectronic devices. We investigated the effects of InAlAs graded-buffer growth for InAs layers in assocn. with a fundamental mechanism of redn. in threading dislocation (TD) d. by the graded buffers. Four InAs layers were grown on semi-insulating GaAs(001) substrates by direct and graded-buffer growth using mol. beam epitaxy. The materials were characterized by using at. force microscopy (AFM), plan-view transmission electron microscopy (PTEM), and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The graded-buffer growth is ineffective for the InAs on GaAs; it is invalid to reduce the InAs near-surface TD d. in comparison with the direct growth, despite its effectiveness for InGa(Al)As below the intermediate indium contents. This can be attributed to a driving force of upward moving of TDs above the intermediate indium contents due to alloy hardening, while the direction of the driving force is downward below the intermediate indium contents.

Short-wave infrared (SWIR) detectors and emitters have a high potential value in several fields of applications, including the internet of things (IoT) and advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS), gas sensing. Indium Gallium Arsenide (InGaAs) photodetectors are widely used in the SWIR region of 1-3 μm; however, they only capture a part of the region due to a cut-off wavelength of 1.7 μm. This study presents an InAs p-i-n photodetector grown on a GaAs substrate (001) by inserting 730-nm thick InxAl1-xAs graded and AlAs buffer layers between the InAs layer and the GaAs substrate. At room temperature, the fabricated InAs photodetector operated in an infrared range of approximately 1.5-4 μm and its detectivity (D(*)) was 1.65 × 10(8) cm · Hz(1/2) · W(-1) at 3.3 μm. To demonstrate performance, the Sherlock Holmes mapping images were obtained using the photodetector at room temperature.

The role of traps in the photocurrent generation mechanism in thin InSe photodetectors
Zhao, Qinghua; Wang, Wei; Carrascoso-Plana, Felix; Jie, Wanqi; Wang, Tao; Castellanos-Gomez, Andres; Frisenda, Riccardo
Materials Horizons
(

),

Due to the excellent elec. transport properties and optoelectronic performance, thin indium selenide (InSe) has recently attracted attention in the field of 2D semiconducting materials. However, the mechanism behind the photocurrent generation in thin InSe photodetectors remains elusive. Here, we present a set of expts. aimed at explaining the strong scattering in the photoresponsivity values reported in the literature for thin InSe photodetectors. By performing optoelectronic measurements on thin InSe-based photodetectors operated under different environmental conditions we find that the photoresponsivity, the response time and the photocurrent power dependency are strongly correlated in this material. This observation indicates that the photogating effect plays an imporant role in thin InSe flakes, and it is the dominant mechanism in the ultra-high photoresponsivity of pristine InSe devices. In addn., when exposing the pristine InSe photodetectors to the ambient environment we observe a fast and irreversible change in the photoresponse, with a decrease in the photoresponsivity accompanied by an increase of the operating speed. We attribute this photodetector performance change (upon atm. exposure) to the decrease in the d. of the traps present in InSe, due to the passivation of selenium vacancies by atm. oxygen species. This passivation is accompanied by a downward shift of the InSe Fermi level and by a decrease of the Fermi level pinning, which leads to an increase of the Schottky barrier between Au and InSe. Our study reveals the important role of traps induced by defects in tailoring the properties of devices based on 2D materials and offers a controllable route to design and functionalize thin InSe photodetectors to realize devices with either ultrahigh photoresposivity or fast operation speed.

We report on SU-8 passivation for performance improvement of type-II InAs/GaSb strained layer superlattice detectors (λcut-off∼4.6 μm). Optical and elec. behavior of SU-8 passivated and non-passivated devices was compared. The dark c.d. was improved by four orders of magnitude for passivated single diodes at 77 K. The zero bias responsivity and detectivity at 77 K was equal to 0.9 A/W and 3.5×1012 Jones for SU-8 passivated single pixel diodes. We demonstrate the high-performance longwavelength InAs/GaSb superlattice (SL) IR photodetectors based on an Al-free single heterojunction grown by metalorg. chem. vapor deposition. The devices feature a mid-wavelength InAs/GaSb SL p-n junction (PN) and a long-wavelength InAs/GaSb SL n-type absorber (n), so-called PNn design, to reduce the dark current. In addn., a shallow-etch technique was employed by exposing only the mid-wavelength materials during pixel isolation to suppress the surface leakage currents. At 77 K and a bias voltage of -0.1 V, the device exhibited a 50% cutoff wavelength at 8.0μ m, a dark c.d. of 2.4 × 10-5 A/cm2, and a peak responsivity of 2.1 A/W. Temp.-dependent dark current measurement indicated the diffusion-limited behavior down to 75 K. The specific detectivity was estd. to be 7.3×1011 cm·Hz1/2/W, which is comparable with that of detectors grown by the mol. beam epitaxy at similar cutoff wavelengths.

The grating coupled GaAs/AlGaAs quantum well IR photodetectors (QWIPs) are integrated onto Si substrates using metal wafer bonding and epitaxial lift-off process. The 1μm depth of hexagonal hole structure of grating was formed. The energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy results confirmed that the grating coupled QWIP is successfully mounted on an Si substrate. By evaluating the Raman spectra, PL, and surface roughness of bonded QWIP samples, the authors found that the grating does not induce any change in the optical or structural characteristics of actual QWIP layers. The dark current-voltage characteristics show a nearly identical dark current level between grating coupled QWIP and nongrating QWIP. The photocurrent spectrum shows that the peak photocurrent intensity of grating coupled QWIP is about 16 times higher than that of nongrating QWIP. This indicates that the grating effectively contributes to an increase in the light absorption of QWIP, showing large room for improvement of QWIP performance by further optimization of a grating structure. We report a mid-IR InAs p-i-n photovoltaic detector on a Si substrate operating at room temp. with a cutoff wavelength at 3.5 μm. The large 11.6% lattice mismatch between the device layer (InAs) and the Si substrate is accommodated by employing a compositionally graded buffer layer technique using solid-source mol. beam epitaxy and a com. available GeSi substrate. An AlxIn1-xAs graded buffer layer is used to linearly scale the lattice const. from AlAs to InAs with an increasing x value. The photovoltaic detector has a responsivity of 0.57 A/W, measured using a blackbody source maintained at 700 °C.

We report an epitaxy growth and characterization of InAs photodetector (PD) on virtual Ge/Si and GaP/Si substrates. The effect of different types of the virtual substrate on the structure and performance of the InAs PD was studied. Although the lattice mismatch between InAs and Si is large (11.6%), close to 100% relaxation of InAs was achieved on both virtual substrates. A higher surface roughness was obsd. in the InAs layer grown GaP/Si as compared with that of Ge/Si. InAs PD with room temp. blackbody specific detectivity of ∼5 × 108 cm·Hz1/2/W is achieved in photovoltaic mode on both types of virtual substrate.
